node.title: Multiapp steady coupled : re-solve mainapp.
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I intend to realize the steady-state coupling of two physical fields u and v through multiapp. The problem is as follows:
Here I use FullSolveMultiApp, where u is mainapp and v is subapp for solving, but I do not know how to achieve the re-solving of u and end the iteration.
Thank you very much for your answers.

Hello
To trigger multiapp fixed point iterations you have to set in the executioner block the fixed_point_max_its parameter
@GiudGiud Do you mean  fixed_point_min_its to force more iterations then needed for convergence?

The trigger for FP iterations is one of these two parameters.
It s on my todo list to trigger on all of them

Thank you for your answers.
I tried again yesterday and probably got it
Here's what I tried.
First, I use the FullSolveMultiApp, u for mainapp, v for subapp, use steady executioner, execute on = timestep_end. The calculation result shows that v is calculated after u is completed.
But what I want is that the program can then update some parameter from v, and then repeatedly compute u and v until the ending condition is satisfied.
I then tried to the cases of execute_on = LINEAR or NONLINEAR, but the convergence was not good.
So, I tried changing the u executioner to be Transient, giving it a large num steps, but setting steady_state_detection = true, and execute_on = 'timestep_end'.
Here, for each time step, u and v will be fully calculated and the parameters will be updated. When satisfies nl_abs_tol, the Transient calculation will be ended, and the calculation speed is also good.
Next, I will try to implement FP-iterations to solve the problem and have a comparison.
Thank you again. Have a nice day.

How are you sure that this is not what is going on?
The default execution of FullSolveMultiapp is TIMESTEP_BEGIN so that means if the "u" is the main app and "v" is the sub app, the order of operations is to first run and solve "v" then finish solving "u".

node.title: fusion_indicator
node.bodyText:
Dear moose developers,
Hello, I defined a new region with the following expression. According to my logic, the region I defined should be marked as 1, but I don't know why they are all marked as 0.5.
[AuxKernels]
  [fusion_indicator]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = fusion_region
    coupled_variables = 'gr0 gr1 bnds'
    expression = 'if(abs(gr0 - 0.5) < 0.1, if(abs(gr1 - 0.5) < 0.1, 1, 0), 0)'
    execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
  []
[]

this is picture of result.

What variable type is fusion region? Some variables have visualization artefacts in paraview.
Is this paraview or peacock or ?
And did you set the color map scale to go from 0 to 1?

Thank you for your reply. For the above problem, I actually wanted to capture some areas belonging to two particles in this way, and use them as the sintered neck (or GB) area. However, when I encountered this problem, I enlarged the scale to 0-1, which is still the case. I don't know if this is correct, or if I have a better way to deal with the sintered neck.

What variable type is fusion region? Some variables have visualization artefacts in paraview.
Is this paraview or peacock or ?

What about this?

actually wanted to capture some areas belonging to two particles in this way, and use them as the sintered neck (or GB) area

Did you use an auxiliary variable to try to find these areas?
EDIT: Ok I see below

I don't know if this is correct, or if I have a better way to deal with the sintered neck.

This looks fine to me. It's just the variable value that's weird

I refer to the determination of the free surface pointed out in the paper of 18 years, and adopt the following code to set up the free surface. Normally, the value of these selected areas should be marked as 1, but here it is 0.5, and I am not sure why. Will it make any difference to my results?

[AuxVariables]
  [free_surface_region]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]
[AuxKernels]
  [free_surface_indicator]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = free_surface_region
    coupled_variables = 'gr0 gr1 c'
    # expression = 'if(c > 0.25, if(c < 0.75, 1, 0), 0)'
    expression = 'if(c > 0.45, if(c < 0.55, 1, 0), 0)'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]
[Postprocessors]
  [free_surface_area]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = free_surface_region
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]

I refer to the determination of the free surface pointed out in the paper of 18 years

which paper? maybe the authors will have some advice

Will it make any difference to my results?

It depends. Are you using fusion_region just as an indicator (non-zero indicates the neck)? Or are you relying on its actual value?
 [AuxVariables]
  [free_surface_region]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

ok this makes sense now!
Constant monomials are computed from the integral of the auxkernel evaluation/
So what is happening is that the auxkernel is evaluating to 1 over half the quadrature points and to 0 over the entire half. So the integral amounts to 0.5

I just want to find the area I need to focus on in this way, and then the area of in the post-processing of the calculated (by ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor). This process has nothing to do with the value of the region, just marking it. However, in moose, I'm not sure that this way of defining variables or post-processing works as well as I thought. Could u give me some advice? thanks.

and then the area of in the post-processing of the calculated (by ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor).

The problem is that the elements are partially in the fusion region and partially outside, this is why it's 0.5
If you want to compute the area, integrating the variable still works. 0.5 over the element is a better approximation than 1 here

Thank you for your reply. But I think I ran into a numerical problem.Specifically, I've defined a region through this code.
[AuxVariables]
  [fusion_region]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fusion_indicatorAuxKernel]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = fusion_region
    coupled_variables = 'gr0 gr1 bnds c'
    expression = 'if(gr0 > 0.45, if(gr0 < 0.55, if(gr1 > 0.45, if(gr1 < 0.55, 1, 0), 0), 0), 0)'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [fusion_area]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = fusion_region
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]

Below I'll show you three consecutive time steps at run time, along with the corresponding area line chart.



From the three consecutive graphs, we can find that the area of the selected area is almost growing by 2 small grids at a time. But the area of the line output in peacock increases dramatically in the third picture (Area in red box). This seems to be due to the increase in the number of markers in the third graph. (In fact, I'm not sure if that's the case, so I need your help.)

How should I set up to solve this problem? (I just want to find the areas that meet the filter criteria and then count the area of the area) Looking forward to your reply.
Can you try to regenerate this plot with 2x more time steps (dt -> dt/2) ? and see if the results we are seeing are converged in time
Sorry for my late reply. This is the result of redrawing. (The time of the above screenshot is t=76, 83, 91)
Did you make the time step twice smaller? This looks the same to me

Do you mean reduced drawing time or simulation time? I used time step adaptive processing. Also, like this, is there a way for me to force a value to the flagged position? (For example, the value assigned here is 1 instead of 0.5)

Use a fixed dT or at least a functionDT
If you don't make the time steps smaller you cannot know whether your results are converged.

Thank you for your reply. I have adopted a fixed time step of 0.01 for calculation. The following is the result diagram.

I have a doubt. You mentioned in your last reply that it is difficult to judge whether the time step is convergent because it is not fixed. I don't understand that the adaptive time step is automatically adjusted according to the convergence. Should I turn on adaptive step size in normal calculations?
And, I want to know is there a way for me to force a value to the flagged position? (For example, the value assigned here is 1 instead of 0.5)

Hello, I now define variables in the following way. I have a question about how to calculate in the postprocessor(ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor) for areas where the variable value is not equal to 1. Since I need the area of my marker area, so I want to know this.
[AuxVariables]
  [fusion_region]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fusion_indicatorAuxKernel]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = fusion_region
    coupled_variables = 'gr0 gr1 bnds c'
    expression = 'if(gr0 > 0.45, if(gr0 < 0.55, if(gr1 > 0.45, if(gr1 < 0.55, 1, 0), 0), 0), 0)'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [fusion_area]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = fusion_region
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]

Perhaps, for me, I want to mark an area in this way, and then calculate its area, which is better? Look forward to your reply and help, thank you.

if you want the area of every element which has a nonzero value, you should create a:

a new CONSTANT monomial variable to store the criterion
use a ParsedAux with logic based on the current fusion_region values. something like this for the expression

(fusion_region > 0, 1, 0)

Thank you for your reply. I have made the following Settings. My target is to get the area of the free surface of two particles. A free surface is defined as c between 0.45 and 0.55.
[AuxVariables]
  [free_surface_region]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  [free_surface_int]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [free_surface_indicatorAuxKernel]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = free_surface_region
    coupled_variables = 'gr0 gr1 c'
    expression = 'if(c > 0.45, if(c < 0.55, 1, 0), 0)'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []

  [free_surface_indicator_intAuxKernel]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = free_surface_int
    coupled_variables = 'free_surface_region'
    expression = 'if(free_surface_region > 0, 1, 0)'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]

[ICs]
  [ic_gr0]
    type = SmoothCircleIC
    invalue = 1.0
    outvalue = 0.0
    radius = 7.5
    variable = gr0
    x1 = 12.5
    y1 = 10
    int_width = 1.9
  []

  [ic_gr1]
    type = SmoothCircleIC
    invalue = 1.0
    outvalue = 0.0
    radius = 7.5
    variable = gr1
    x1 = 27.5
    y1 = 10
    int_width = 1.9
  []

  [ic_c]
    type = SpecifiedSmoothCircleIC
    invalue = 1.0
    outvalue = 0.0
    radii = '7.5 7.5'
    variable = c
    x_positions = '12.5 27.5'
    y_positions = '10.0 10.0'
    z_positions = '0.0 0.0'
    int_width = 1.9
    3D_spheres = false
    block = 0
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [free_surface_area_int]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = free_surface_int
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []

  [free_surface_int_area_initial]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = free_surface_int
    execute_on = 'initial'
    # outputs = none
  []

  [free_surface_int_area_relative_percentage]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    expression = '100 * (free_surface_area_int - free_surface_int_area_initial) / free_surface_int_area_initial'
    pp_names = 'free_surface_area_int free_surface_int_area_initial'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  l_tol = 1e-05
  l_max_its = 30
  nl_max_its = 15
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-04
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-04
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 100.0
  dt = 0.1
  [Adaptivity]
    initial_adaptivity = 2
    refine_fraction = 0.8 
    coarsen_fraction = 0.05 
    max_h_level = 3
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
  execute_on = "initial timestep_end"
  checkpoint = true
  solution_history = true
[]

I'm not sure if I'm setting this up correctly, but I'm having a few problems. For example, my free surface varies significantly more than reported in the literature. In addition, according to my initialization conditions, the initial free surface should be the circumference of two spherical particles, but I encountered the following situation.


It looks like there are some mistakes. Can you give me some advice?

This isn't the right approach to measure a perimeter or a surface. To do that you would need to run a line through the elements that mark the boundary, and measure its length.
I think there is already machinery to measure surfaces of grains in the phase field module. Did you try to find that?
I looked up the Complete Syntax, but I didn't find any related app for free surfaces, could you provide some references

Ok you'll need to make an object then.
I would say to try a user object that evaluated the true path of that line (in 2D) / surface (in 3D) by first placing its points in the middle of the elements with a nonzero value (or at the maximum?)

I found an object, GrainBoundaryArea. Does it help me with my needs? I tried to experiment with him, and my two particles had an initial diameter of 15, but he output 47.1, which is the circumference of a particle.
  [bnd_length] 
    type = GrainBoundaryArea
    grains_per_side = 2.0
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []

47 could be 15 * pi
And the factor of 2 is in the grains per side
I think this is the right object

Thanks for your reply, so does grains_per_side = 2.0 mean total grain boundary length divided by 2? In addition, when two particles touch, can the contact area (circled in the graph) be included by GrainBoundaryArea?

I just checked the definition and no it's not that.
You ll want to experiment with it to compute the contact area. You might need to modify it

node.title: save question
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Dear moose Community,
Hello, I have a question about saving. I output the following Settings, I can output.e files normally before, but I suddenly found that I output a series of such files,.e files only save the result of the first time step. In addition, I can view it normally in peacock.

Paraview will understand these -s00x extensions
This is due to using either adaptivity or mesh modifications
Thank you for your guidance

node.title: Writing a .i file to study the impact of temperature gradient on grain growth in a bicrystal system
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am trying to reproduce grain growth for a bicrystal system in the presence of a temperature gradient as an external field. I wrote a .i file based on the equations mentioned in the paper.
I am not able to find any output. Kindly help in this regards.

(https://github.com/user-attachments/files/18279534/Michael.R_2013.pdf)
[Mesh]
type = GeneratedMesh
dim = 2
nx = 20
ny = 10
xmin = 0
xmax = 20
ymin = 0
ymax = 10
[]
[GlobalParams]
block = 0
[]
[Variables]
[./eta1]
[../]
[./eta2]
[../]
[./T]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[]
[ICs]
[./IC_eta1]
x1 = 0
y1 = 0
x2 = 20
y2 = 10
inside = 1.0
outside = 0.0
type = BoundingBoxIC
variable = eta1
int_width = 0.5
[../]
[./IC_eta2]
x1 = 10
y1 = 0
x2 = 20
y2 = 10
inside = 1.0
outside = 0.0
type = BoundingBoxIC
variable = eta2
int_width = 0.5
[../]
[./T]
x1 = 0
y1 = 0
x2 = 18
y2 = 10
inside = 0.01
outside = 0.01
type = BoundingBoxIC
variable = T
int_width = 0.5
[../]
[]
[AuxVariables]
[./T_x]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./T_y]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./eta1_x]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./eta1_y]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./eta2_x]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./eta2_y]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[]
[AuxKernels]
[./T_x]
type = VariableGradientComponent
variable = T_x
component = x
gradient_variable = T
[../]
[./T_y]
type = VariableGradientComponent
variable = T_y
component = y
gradient_variable = T
[../]
[./eta1_x]
type =VariableGradientComponent
variable = eta1_x
component = x
gradient_variable = eta1
[../]
[./eta1_y]
type =VariableGradientComponent
variable = eta1_y
component = y
gradient_variable = eta1
[../]
[./eta2_x]
type =VariableGradientComponent
variable = eta2_x
component = x
gradient_variable = eta2
[../]
[./eta2_y]
type =VariableGradientComponent
variable = eta2_y
component = y
gradient_variable = eta2
[../]
[]
[Kernels]
[./AC1_bulk]
type = AllenCahn
variable = eta1
f_name = F
args = 'eta2 T '
[../]
[./AC1_int]
type = ACInterface
variable = eta1
kappa_name = kappa_s
[../]
[./e1_dot]
type = TimeDerivative
variable = eta1
[../]
[./AC2_bulk]
type = AllenCahn
variable = eta2
f_name = F
args = 'eta1 T '
[../]
[./AC2_int]
type = ACInterface
variable = eta2
kappa_name = kappa_s
[../]
[./e2_dot]
type = TimeDerivative
variable = eta2
[../]
[./diff2]
type = Diffusion
variable = T
[../]
[]
[Materials]
[./FreeEng]
type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
args = 'eta1 eta2 T_x T_y eta1_x eta1_y eta2_x eta2_y  T'
f_name = F
constant_names = ' ww'
constant_expressions = ' 1.14 '
function = 'f2:=(1/4eta1^4-1/2eta1^2+1/4eta2^4-1/2eta2^2);
f3:=s*(eta1^2eta2^2);
f4:=eta14.0*(T_xeta1_x+T_yeta1_y);
f5:=eta24.0(T_xeta2_x+T_yeta2_y);
    F:= ww*(f2 + f3 + 0.25) + f4 + f5;F'

derivative_order = 2
outputs = exodus
[../]
[./const]
type = GenericConstantMaterial
prop_names = 'kappa_s L '
prop_values = '1.0 1.0 '
outputs = exodus
[../]
[]
[BCs]
[./Periodic]
[./all]
auto_direction = 'y'
[../]
[../]
[./neumaan1]
type = NeumannBC
boundary = 'left right'
variable = eta1
value = 0
[../]
[./neumaan2]
type = NeumannBC
boundary = 'left right'
variable = eta2
value = 0
[../]
[./Dirichlet1]
type = DirichletBC
boundary = 'left'
variable = T
value = 0.1
[../]
[./Dirichlet2]
type = DirichletBC
boundary = 'right'
variable = T
value = 1.5
[../]
[]
[Postprocessors]
[./dt]
type = TimestepSize
[../]
[]
[Preconditioning]
active = ' '
[./SMP]
type = SMP
full = true
petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -snes_atol -snes_rtol -ksp_rtol -pc_type -build_twosided'
petsc_options_value = ' 160 1e-10 1e-8 1e-6 bjacobi allreduce'
[../]
[]
[Executioner]
type = Transient
scheme = BDF2
solve_type = newton
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_grmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
petsc_options_value = 'asm 31 preonly lu 1'
l_max_its = 30
nl_abs_tol = 1e-7
l_tol = 1e-7
nl_max_its = 30
nl_rel_tol = 1e-7
end_time = 30000000
dt=0.50
[]
[Outputs]
execute_on = 'timestep_end'
exodus = true
interval=2
[]
You should have an exodus file output. Look in the folder where you ran the input, with a .e file extension

Yes, it generated an output file with a .e extension, but when I tried to plot it in ParaView, I encountered the following error.
Please find attachment.

Could you please let me know the correct flow for defining auxiliary variables, kernels, periodic boundary conditions, and the free energy? Did I define them correctly.
Ive never seen this before. It looks like you have a field output twice. Can you remove it from the material property output?

node.title: Something went wrong when using ReferenceResidualProblem
node.bodyText:
When using ReferenceResidualProblem, the following error is reported, but I don't know why
*** ERROR ***
/home/Rookie07/project_202408/bees/HCF/normal_operations.i:9.1:
The following error occurred in the Problem 'MOOSE Problem' of type ReferenceResidualProblem.

Unable to find function

hello
what does your input file look like?
The Problem is attempting to retrieve a function, seemingly with an empty name, so an object must be requesting that from the problem

I searched my input card once, but I didn't find any empty input for function，
If it were really possible, it might happen in the following place
[Functions]
  [./power_profile]
    type = PiecewiseLinear  # reads and interpolation an input file containing rod average linear power vs time
    #data_file = history_qbw_new.csv
    data_file = peak_linear_power.csv
    format = columns
  [../]
  [./axial_peaking_factors]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 1.0
  [../]
  [./coolant_pressure]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 15.5e6
  [../]
  [./q]
    type = CompositeFunction
    functions = 'power_profile axial_peaking_factors'
  [../]
  [./factor]
    type = PowerSurfaceTopFactor
    fuel_diameter = 6.83e-3
    fuel_length =  0.36
  [../]
  [./average_surface_power]
    type = CompositeFunction
    functions = 'power_profile factor'
  [../]
[]
can you reproduce the error with just this block?

This input card is very long, and it's more complicated, I just looked at the part of the function, and it may not be the problem here, but when I change the axial_oeaking_factors option in the functions of the q function to factors, it will report an error that the factor function does not exist, so I wonder if it is a problem here

node.title: Regarding Moose installation on HPC Cluster
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am trying to install MOOSE on our HPC cluster. I followed all the instructions mentioned on the MOOSE HPC Installation Guide.
Here are the steps I followed:
(a) Currently Loaded Modules (as required for installing MOOSE on the HPC cluster):

1. python/conda-python/3.9
2. compiler/gcc/13.1.0
3. cmake/3.28.1
4. compiler/openmpi/gcc/4.0.2

(b) Activate Environment: Activated the desired MPI environment.
(c) Cloning MOOSE: Successfully cloned the MOOSE repository.
(d) PETSc, libMesh, and WASP:

Successfully ran the PETSc command.
However, while installing libMesh, I encountered the following error:
 *********************************************************************
                                        ERROR
********************************************************************
make[4]: Leaving directory `/home/rakeshm22/projects/moose/libmesh/build/contrib/netcdf/v4/libhdf5'
Making all in liblib
make[4]: Entering directory `/home/rakeshm22/projects/moose/libmesh/build/contrib/netcdf/v4/liblib'
  CC       libnetcdf_la-nc_initialize.lo
  CCLD     libnetcdf.la
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -ludev
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make[4]: *** [libnetcdf.la] Error 1
make[4]: Leaving directory `/home/rakeshm22/projects/moose/libmesh/build/contrib/netcdf/v4/liblib'
make[3]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make[3]: Leaving directory `/home/rakeshm22/projects/moose/libmesh/build/contrib/netcdf/v4'
make[2]: *** [all] Error 2
make[2]: Leaving directory `/home/rakeshm22/projects/moose/libmesh/build/contrib/netcdf/v4'
make[1]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/rakeshm22/projects/moose/libmesh/build/contrib'
make: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
**********************************************************************************************************

Hello
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -ludev

This is a missing dependency in your environment.
you need to install it locally or get your cluster admins to make it available to you in another module
if you have admin rights and apt-get is installed (unlikely) you can just run
sudo apt-get install --reinstall libudev-devel

Hello GuidGiud,
Thank you for your response.
I am not a sudo user, so I kindly request your guidance on how to install it locally and resolve this issue. Your assistance would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you again for your help.

I have never installed libudev from source. I m not sure how easy it is.
can you see if you can find it in the modules?
module avail

should show everything you can load.
Your HPC team might also know if you they already have it with modules for different compiler stack

Hello everyone,
I am trying to reproduce grain growth for a bicrystal system in the presence of a temperature gradient as an external field. I wrote a .i file based on the equations mentioned in the paper.
I am not able to find any output. Kindly help in this regards.
(https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/796e1709-6867-4548-955e-a7407dd1719a)
(https://github.com/user-attachments/files/18279534/Michael.R_2013.pdf)

[Mesh]
type = GeneratedMesh
dim = 2
nx = 20
ny = 10
xmin = 0
xmax = 20
ymin = 0
ymax = 10
[]
[GlobalParams]
block = 0
[]
[Variables]
[./eta1]
[../]
[./eta2]
[../]
[./T]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[]
[ICs]
[./IC_eta1]
x1 = 0
y1 = 0
x2 = 20
y2 = 10
inside = 1.0
outside = 0.0
type = BoundingBoxIC
variable = eta1
int_width = 0.5
[../]
[./IC_eta2]

y1 = 0
x2 = 20
y2 = 10
inside = 1.0
outside = 0.0
type = BoundingBoxIC
variable = eta2
int_width = 0.5
[../]
[./T]
x1 = 0
y1 = 0
x2 = 18
y2 = 10
inside = 0.01
outside = 0.01
type = BoundingBoxIC
variable = T
int_width = 0.5
[../]
[]
[AuxVariables]
[./T_x]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./T_y]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./eta1_x]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./eta1_y]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./eta2_x]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./eta2_y]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[]
[AuxKernels]
[./T_x]
type = VariableGradientComponent
variable = T_x
component = x
gradient_variable = T
[../]
[./T_y]
type = VariableGradientComponent
variable = T_y
component = y
gradient_variable = T
[../]
[./eta1_x]
type =VariableGradientComponent
variable = eta1_x
component = x
gradient_variable = eta1
[../]
[./eta1_y]
type =VariableGradientComponent
variable = eta1_y
component = y
gradient_variable = eta1
[../]
[./eta2_x]

component = x
gradient_variable = eta2
[../]
[./eta2_y]

variable = eta2_y
component = y
gradient_variable = eta2
[../]
[]
[Kernels]
[./AC1_bulk]
type = AllenCahn
variable = eta1
f_name = F
args = 'eta2 T '
[../]
[./AC1_int]
type = ACInterface
variable = eta1
kappa_name = kappa_s
[../]
[./e1_dot]
type = TimeDerivative
variable = eta1
[../]
[./AC2_bulk]
type = AllenCahn
variable = eta2
f_name = F
args = 'eta1 T '
[../]
[./AC2_int]
type = ACInterface
variable = eta2
kappa_name = kappa_s
[../]
[./e2_dot]
type = TimeDerivative
variable = eta2
[../]
[./diff2]
type = Diffusion
variable = T
[../]
[]
[Materials]
[./FreeEng]
type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
args = 'eta1 eta2 T_x T_y eta1_x eta1_y eta2_x eta2_y  T'

f_name = F

constant_names = ' ww'  
constant_expressions = ' 1.14 '

function = 'f2:=(1/4eta1^4-1/2eta1^2+1/4eta2^4-1/2eta2^2);
f3:=s*(eta1^2eta2^2);
f4:=eta14.0*(T_xeta1_x+T_yeta1_y);
f5:=eta24.0(T_xeta2_x+T_yeta2_y);
        F:= ww*(f2 + f3 + 0.25) + f4 + f5;F'

derivative_order = 2
outputs = exodus
[../]
[./const]
type = GenericConstantMaterial
prop_names = 'kappa_s L '
prop_values = '1.0 1.0 '
outputs = exodus
[../]
[]
[BCs]
[./Periodic]
[./all]
auto_direction = 'y'
[../]
[../]
[./neumaan1]

boundary = 'left right'
variable = eta1
value = 0
[../]

variable = eta2
value = 0
[../]

[../]

value = 1.5
[../]

[../]
[]
[Preconditioning]

[./SMP]

full = true

petsc_options_value = '    160            1e-10      1e-8      1e-6       bjacobi       allreduce'
[../]
[]
[Executioner]

scheme = BDF2
solve_type = newton
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_grmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'

l_max_its = 30
nl_abs_tol = 1e-7

nl_rel_tol = 1e-7
end_time = 30000000
dt=0.50
[]
[Outputs]
execute_on = 'timestep_end'
exodus = true
interval=2
[]

hello
please open a different post, the topic of this discussion is HPC installation not phase field

node.title: Issue with SLEPc installation during MOOSE setup on old HPC system
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
Hello everyone,
I’m currently trying to install MOOSE on an HPC platform with an outdated system, and I'm unable to update the system, which is why I cannot use conda for installation. A while ago, I managed to install some of MOOSE’s dependencies (specifically the Python environment) using conda, and then followed the ‘Offline Installation’ guide to successfully install MOOSE by running the following command:
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh --skip-submodule-update --with-packages-download-dir=~/projects/downloads || return
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh --skip-submodule-update || return
./update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh --skip-submodule-update || return

However, when I try to install PETSc on a new account using the same method, I encounter the following error:
*** Building SLEPc ***
Checking environment... done
Checking PETSc installation... Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/public3/home/a0s000425/ZhangHu-MOOSE/projects/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/slepc-2e87c100eacb3466e83737e0fd6f542957174390/./configure", line 12, in <module>
    exec(f.read())
  File "<string>", line 263, in <module>
  File "/public3/home/a0s000425/ZhangHu-MOOSE/projects/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/slepc-2e87c100eacb3466e83737e0fd6f542957174390/config/packages/petsc.py", line 226, in Process
    slepcdate = dateutil.parser.parse(slepc.gitdate)
  File "/public3/home/a0s000425/ZhangHu-MOOSE/minforge/envs/moose-py/lib/python3.9/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py", line 1368, in parse
    return DEFAULTPARSER.parse(timestr, **kwargs)
  File "/public3/home/a0s000425/ZhangHu-MOOSE/minforge/envs/moose-py/lib/python3.9/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py", line 643, in parse
    raise ParserError("Unknown string format: %s", timestr)
dateutil.parser._parser.ParserError: Unknown string format: unknown
**************************ERROR*************************************
Error building SLEPc.
********************************************************************
gmake[2]: *** [slepcbuild] Error 1
**************************ERROR*************************************
  Error during compile, check arch-moose/lib/petsc/conf/make.log
  Send it and arch-moose/lib/petsc/conf/configure.log to petsc-maint@mcs.anl.gov
  Having Conda in your shell may have caused this problem, consider turning off Conda.
********************************************************************
make[1]: *** [all] Error 1
make: *** [all] Error 2
There was an error. Exiting...
-bash: return: can only `return' from a function or sourced script

I have tried turning off conda and also added the conda environment paths to PATH, LD_LIBRARY_PATH, and CPATH (thinking that this would allow me to use the libraries even when conda is deactivated). Unfortunately, this only removed the warning about needing to turn off conda, but the error persists.
Does anyone have suggestions on how to resolve this issue?
(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

Hello
If I understand properly, you installed it once, and are now trying to install from a user account (rather than as an admin)
Do you have permission over the folders where petsc was initially installed?

No, both installations were done with user permissions, and they were on different partitions of the HPC system (although the compute nodes in both partitions have identical physical configurations, the login nodes have different CPUs—one is Intel, and the other is AMD. Additionally, the GCC and MPI module versions are slightly different, but the conda environment is exactly the same). Since the installation was done in the user directory, I have permission to access the PETSc installation location.

Additionally, the GCC and MPI module versions are slightly different,

no part of the install can be shared then.
You must make sure that the two installs are completely separate. When installing the second one, check the environment to make sure there's no contamination.
you can use the diagnostics script in moose/scripts to look at the relevant environment variables

The two installations were done under different accounts, so their home directories are completely separate. Therefore, the installation directories for both MOOSE installations are also completely different, with no sharing between them.

I'd like to check though
what is the output of the diagnostics script?

Here’s the output from running diagnostics.sh

Influential Environment Variables

This makes me uneasy
/public3/soft/intel/2020u4/compilers_and_libraries_2020.4.304/linux/mpi/intel64/libfabric/lib

we dont support the intel compilers. It looks like the environment variables for the compilers are set up for GCC/Gfortran, but LD_LIBRARY_PATH is not clearly setup for GCC/Gfortran

node.title: FunctionValuePostprocessor to printout the values read by PiecewiseMultilinear
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
All,
I am using FunctionValuePostprocessor in Postprocessors to printout the values of a file read by PiecewiseMultilinear in Functions but it is seemingly not working (I got just zeros).
Please help. S.Thomas
Did you check the execute_on parameter? Is it being executed often enough?

Thank you, GiudGiud!
I set as
execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'

The file read by PiecewiseMultilinear in Functions has a form of
AXIS Y
xxx xxx xxx .... xxx
AXIS T
yyy yyy yyy ... yyy
DATA
zzz zzz zzz ... zzz
.
.
zzz zzz zzz ... zzz
So, we may have to sum the values in DATA for AXIS Y at each time step?
FunctionElementIntegral may help?

the FunctionValuePP is only computing one value of the function, at the origin (x=0, y=0, z=0) by default
if you want an integral then I agree FunctionElementIntegral does it

node.title: Request for Assistance with `free(): invalid next size (fast)` Error in Material Class
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am encountering a free(): invalid next size (fast) error in one of my material classes within the Moose application.
The function computeQpStress() successfully executes for each of the 8 _qps, which I verified using the VSCode GDB debugger.  Afterwards, computeQpStress() executes successfully again for all 8 _qps.The output up to that point looks like this:
Time Step 1, time = 5e-06, dt = 5e-06  
Currently Executing  
    Computing Pre-SMO Residual  
      Computing Residual                                                                 [ 24.14 s] [  208 MB]  
Pre-SMO residual: 8e-08  
 Skipping predictor this step  
    Finished Computing Pre-SMO Residual                                                  [ 24.14 s] [  208 MB]  
    Computing Residual.....                                                              [ 39.61 s] [  208 MB]  

However, the issue arises when the code reaches the following section in NonlinearSystem.C (located at /framework/src/systems/NonlinearSystem.C, lines 190–197):
if (time_integrator_solve)  
  mooseAssert(_time_integrators.size() == 1,  
              "If solve is overridden, then there must be only one time integrator");  

if (time_integrator_solve)  
  _time_integrators.front()->solve();  
else  
  system().solve();  
The moment the code executes system().solve();, the application crashes with the following error:
free(): invalid next size (fast) error  

Single stepping until exit from function libmesh_petsc_snes_residual,  
which has no line number information.  
Single stepping until exit from function SNESComputeFunction,  
which has no line number information.  
Single stepping until exit from function SNESSolve_NEWTONLS,  
which has no line number information.  

Thread 1 "rhocp-dbg" received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.  
__pthread_kill_implementation (no_tid=0, signo=6, threadid=<optimized out>) at ./nptl/pthread_kill.c:44  

Notably, other material classes in my Moose application are functioning correctly, and I’m unable to pinpoint the root cause of this issue.
I would greatly appreciate your guidance on troubleshooting and resolving this problem.
Thank you for your help!
Best regards,
Vikram Roy

Hello
If you are already running this using a debugger, can you print a backtrace? You use a breakpoint on the error (if you're lucky b MPI_Abort should suffice), then the execution stops there and you can use bt to get a full backtrace.
You ll want to compile in debug mode to get the line number

Hi Giud,
Thankyou for reply.
This is the backtrace, I get from the GDB Debugger:

This is from the system class not the material. Unfortunately, unless rebuild everything from source in debug mode we wont get lines for libmesh and petsc

But all other material  classes are working fine
I m experiencing this type of error only for this material class

Is it stateful? Does it use old and older values of material properties?
if so try setting snesmf_reuse_base=false in the executioner. It's just a hunch

are these old variable values?
  std::copy(_state_var_old[_qp].begin(), _state_var_old[_qp].end(), _state_var[_qp].begin());
These are old state variables
Make sure the current properties are sized correctly before copying.  std::copy does not allocate space.

node.title: How to solve thermal expansion problems with tens (or hundreds) of gas gap?
node.bodyText:
This geometry always appears in the solid nuclear reactor core: cylinder and hollow cylinders with the same axial line - rod, gas gap, clad, shown in this figure(top view):

I want to solve the thermal expansion for this problem.

A natural thought is to only model rod and clad mesh. The mesh volumes remain void on the gas gap position. I use HeatConduction and HeatSource Kernels, [Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]. The temperature on the outer side of the rod or inner side of the clad is got from GapHeatTransfer. This method will be feasible for only one channel in this picture. But for tens or hundreds channels? It will cost lots of time which is unacceptable.
Another thought is to use different domains for Heat Conduction Module and Solid Mechanics Module: For Heat Conduction Module - rod, gas gap, clad; For Solid Mechanics Module:  rod, clad. But in this method, I encounter an error about negative Jacobian

This method I cannot know the way to achieve it. Omit the gas gap for both rod and clad. In the Heat Conduction Module, try to make the temperature abrupt change to represent the thermal resistance caused by gas gap. In the Solid Mechanics Module, the displacement for the rod block and clad block is the same based on the assumption. However, I cannot find the way to achieve this....
So what's your suggestions? Do you know how to solve thermal expansion problems with tens (or hundreds) of gas gap, or find ways to achieve 3)?

hello
this is likely covered in the BISON manual, which is available online
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/bison/
BISON is an application dedicated to these applications. I would recommend you ask for access here https://ncrcaims.inl.gov/Identity/Account/Login It might take a while to get access considering your current affiliation
